results.webTitle: CSKA Moscow v Tottenham Hotspur: Champions League – as it happened

results.firPara: Pep Guardiola has said he is not concerned about a little record as Manchester City face Celtic in the Champions League on Wednesday night. His side have won all 10 games this season and if they prevail at Celtic Park in the Group C game they will equal Tottenhams record-setting 11 successive wins at the start of the 1960-61 season.
results.secPara: Guardiola does not care about records, he is only interested in adding another victory to the 4-0 defeat of Borussia Mönchengladbach in their opening group game.
results.webTitle: Pep Guardiola tells Manchester City to ignore ‘little record’ at Celtic

results.firPara: Gerardo Tata Martino, the former Argentina coach who quit after failing to lift this summers Copa América Centenario, will take charge of Atlanta United in their first season in MLS next year.
results.secPara: Martino was confirmed on Tuesday as the clubs inaugural head coach. The 53-year-old resigned from his Argentina post in July in protest at what he called serious problems at the Argentinian FA, and Atlanta have spent the past couple of months negotiating to bring him to America.
results.webTitle: Atlanta United appoint former Argentina boss Tata Martino as first head coach

results.firPara: Revie succeeded Alf Ramsey as England manager in 1974 but, having failed to qualify for the 1976 European Championship and with his relationship strained with the Football Association chairman Sir Harold Thompson, he started sounding out prospective employers. He missed a friendly with Brazil in Rio apparently to scout Italy but, in truth, to travel to Dubai to negotiate a four-year contract to manage the United Arab Emirates worth £340,000 annually. He then sold news of his departure to the Daily Mail before the FA had received his formal resignation letter.
results.secPara: The FA duly suspended Revie from football for 10 years, a ban which was overturned in court after a ruling that the governing body had overreached its powers. Yet it transpired that the Daily Mirror had actually been conducting a lengthy enquiry into suggestions Revie had been fixing matches, details of which were later handed to the FA in a 315-page dossier. Revie sued the Mirror for libel, but did not pursue his legal action.
results.webTitle: England managers and off-field controversies: from Revie to Hodgson

results.firPara: Theo Walcott believes his upturn in form is down to a change in attitude that should have happened a few years ago.
results.secPara: Last season was a disappointing one for Walcott, culminating in him missing out on the England squad for the European Championship. After a summer of reflection and a conversation with Arsène Wenger he has scored three goals in six Premier League games, abandoning plans to establish himself as a centre-forward in the process.
results.webTitle: Theo Walcott admits credits new work ethic with transforming his Arsenal form

results.firPara: The Football Association hierarchy are holding a series of emergency meetings at Wembley, with pressure mounting on the England manager, Sam Allardyce, after allegations he offered advice on how to circumvent the governing bodys rules on player transfers.
results.secPara: The FAs recently appointed chairman, Greg Clarke, is speaking with the chief executive, Martin Glenn, to discuss the comments made by Allardyce to undercover reporters from the Daily Telegraph. The hierarchy are understood to be disturbed by the allegations, which were made in two meetings secretly filmed in London and Manchester and which surfaced just 67 days after Allardyce had secured what he had claimed was his dream job. He now faces the prospect of losing the position after only one match in charge.
results.webTitle: Sam Allardyce fights to save England manager’s job in FA crisis talks
